Maximum commercially available capacity: 512 GB (CF5 {{nowrap|128*250 bytes)}}
Main features: Thinner (3.3 mm), flash only, now up to 512 GB, although standard goes up to 128 PB since CF 5.0[2]

Standards organizations: Thicker (5.0 mm), older flash, but usually Microdrives, up to 128 PiB[2]

Maximum commercially available capacity: 1TB
Main features: XQD form factor (38.5 mm × 29.8 mm), PCIe 3.0 x2 (2,0 GB/s), NVMe

Maximum commercially available capacity: PCIe 3.0 x8 (8,0 GB/s), NVMe
128 MB
Main features: Very slim (45.0×37.0×0.76 mm), no wear leveling controller, up to 128 MB. This particular example shows the write protect sticker (the silver disc).

Maximum commercially available capacity: 16 GB
Main features: Slim and small (24×32×1.4 mm), up to 16 GB

Maximum commercially available capacity: Compact (24×18×1.4 mm), up to 16 GB
Compact (24×32×1.4 mm), swifter, optional DRM, up to 16 GB
Subcompact (14×12×1.1 mm), optional DRM, 16 MB to 4 GB
4 GB
Main features: Small (32×24×2.1 mm), DRM, up to 4 GB. (2 GB and 4 GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See Article)

Maximum commercially available capacity: Compact (21.5×20×1.4 mm), DRM, up to 4 GB. (2 GB and 4 GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See Article)
Subcompact (15×11×1 mm), DRM, up to 4 GB. (2 GB and 4 GB cards use larger block sizes and may not be compatible with some host devices. See Article)
Same build as SD but greater capacity and transfer speed, 4 GB to 32 GB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as miniSD but greater capacity and transfer speed, 4 GB to 32 GB. 8 GB is largest in early-2011 (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as microSD but greater capacity and transfer speed, 4 GB to 32 GB.[3](not compatible with older host devices)
Same build as SD/SDHC, but greater capacity and transfer speed, 32 GB and higher. Standard goes up to 2 TB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as microSD/microSDHC, but greater capacity and transfer speed, 32 GB and higher. Standard goes up to 2 TB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as SD/SDHC/SDXC, but greater capacity and transfer speed. Standard goes up to 128 TB (not compatible with older host devices).
Same build as microSD/microSDHC/microSDXC, but greater capacity and transfer speed. Standard goes up to 128 TB (not compatible with older host devices)
128 MB
Main features: Slim and narrow (50×21.5×2.8 mm), optional DRM, up to 128 MB

Maximum commercially available capacity: Slim and narrow (50×21.5×2.8 mm), swifter, optional DRM, up to 4 GB
Compact (31×20×1.6 mm), optional DRM, up to 128 MB
Compact (31×20×1.6 mm), optional DRM, up to 32 GB
Compact (31×20×1.6 mm), swifter, optional DRM, up to 32 GB
Subcompact (15×12.5×1.2 mm), optional DRM, up to 16 GB

Picture[1]: Subcompact (15×12.5×1.6 mm[4]), compulsory DRM, up to 64 GB, proprietary (can be used on PS Vita only)

Maximum commercially available capacity: >2 TB
Main features: High-capacity, high-speed standard using PCIe as interface

Maximum commercially available capacity: 512 MB
Main features: Slim and small (20×25×1.78 mm), electrically identical to SmartMedia, no wear-leveling controller, up to 512 MB[5]

Maximum commercially available capacity: Slim and small (20×25×1.78 mm) but slower read/write, no wear-leveling controller, up to 2 GB[5]
Slim and small (20×25×1.78 mm) and swifter, no wear-leveling controller, up to 2 GB[5]

Main features: Packages the flash memory, currently soldered in shipping smartphones, into a removable card form factor. Uses the SCSI command set including queuing. The electrical interface makes use of differential signaling, which enables high bus speeds and robustness under noisy conditions and reduced pin count (compared to parallel bus alternatives such as UHS-I).

Maximum commercially available capacity: 1 TB+
Main features: Universally compatible across most non-mobile computer platforms, their greater size suits them better to file transfer/storage instead of use in portable devices
